On examination, the right eye appears red with a hazy cornea and dilated pupil that responds poorly to light. Visual acuity in the affected eye is severely diminished. Which of the following medications was most likely used by this patient?

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to abdominal pain. She has had intermittent "aches and cramps" in her abdomen for the past few weeks. The patient denies nausea, vomiting, or a change in appetite or bowel movements. Her stress level has been higher than normal since her boyfriend broke off their relationship a month ago. She says, "We were together for 10 years, and he abandoned me. I don't know how to go on without him." The patient starts crying when discussing how her boyfriend managed her finances and recently helped her apply for a new job. She is unsure about switching jobs now and cancelled her interviews to "avoid more confusion." She recently moved in with a friend and hopes this person can help her "sort everything out."  Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient's behaviour?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dependent personality disorder

 

This patient demonstrates excessive need to be cared for, difficulty making everyday decisions without reassurance, fear of abandonment, and seeking new relationships for support — all hallmark features of Dependent Personality Disorder (DPD).


She is unable to function independently after her breakup and immediately seeks another caregiver (“moved in with a friend to help her sort everything out”).

 

Core features of Dependent Personality Disorder:

 

  • Difficulty making decisions without reassurance
  • Fear of being left alone
  • Submissive and clingy behaviour
  • Urgent need to establish new relationships when one ends
  • Lack of self-confidence and autonomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute stress disorder: Develops after a traumatic event (e.g., accident, assault) with intrusive memories, dissociation, hyperarousal; not applicable here, as the stressor is interpersonal and not traumatic.

 

Option B. Adjustment disorder: Emotional or behavioural symptoms within 3 months of a stressor, causing distress but not meeting criteria for another disorder. Here, the pattern of long-standing dependency and fear of abandonment suggests a personality trait, not a short-term maladaptive response.

 

Option C. Somatic symptom disorder: Involves excessive anxiety about physical symptoms (pain, fatigue) disproportionate to any medical cause. Her abdominal pain is mild and secondary to emotional stress, not the focus of preoccupation.

questions.text: A female presents with loss of vision in the right halves of both eyes. Where is the lesion located in the optic pathway?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left optic tract

 

The patient has loss of vision in the right halves of both visual fields — that is right homonymous hemianopia (right temporal field loss in left eye + right nasal field loss in right eye).

 

This indicates a lesion posterior to the optic chiasma, because:

 

  • Pre-chiasmal (optic nerve) lesions cause monocular vision loss.
  • Chiasmal lesions cause bitemporal hemianopia.
  • Post-chiasmal lesions (optic tract, optic radiation, occipital cortex) cause homonymous field defects.

 

In this case, since the right visual field of both eyes is lost, the lesion must be on the left side of the visual pathway — specifically, the left optic tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right optic radiation: Would produce left homonymous hemianopia (loss of left visual fields), not right.

 

Option C. Optic chiasma: Causes bitemporal hemianopia, due to compression of crossing nasal fibers — both temporal fields lost, not homonymous.

 

Option D. Right optic tract: Would cause left homonymous hemianopia, the opposite side of what is described.

 

SUMMARY:

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to persistent nasal congestion and stuffiness. A year ago, she came to the emergency department due to severe wheezing after taking naproxen for menstrual cramping. HRCT of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C﻿) ﻿Nasal polyposis

 

The patient’s history of severe wheezing after NSAID use and current HRCT showing multiple bilateral soft tissue densities in the nasal cavity points to nasal polyposis. This scenario fits the classic triad of aspirin sensitivity, asthma, and nasal polyps (Samter’s triad).

 

Thus, the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is Nasal polyposis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic rhinitis: Often presents on imaging as mucosal thickening and turbinate swelling without the formation of discrete polypoid masses. The inflammatory changes are generally confined to the mucosa and do not cause significant expansion or opacification of the sinus cavities. 

 

Option B. Fungal rhinosinusitis: Particularly the allergic or invasive forms, is characterized on CT by the presence of hyperdense areas representing allergic mucin or fungal elements, frequently accompanied by bone erosion or aggressive sinus expansion.

 

Option D. Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Is a highly vascular benign tumor, nearly exclusive to adolescent males, presenting with recurrent epistaxis and a soft tissue mass in the nasopharynx, often leading to characteristic anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Holman-Miller sign); it is neither typical in adult females nor associated with diffuse nasal or sinus opacification.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the OPD after his wife noted that his eyes appeared different. Medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus.  On physical examination, the right pupil is 3 mm, and the left pupil is 5 mm. When the light in the examination room is dimmed, the anisocoria increases. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right sympathetic pathway

 

Anisocoria that increases in the dark means the smaller pupil fails to dilate → a sympathetic (dilator) defect in that eye. Here, the right pupil is smaller (3 mm) and doesn’t dilate appropriately in dim light → right-sided sympathetic pathway lesion (Horner syndrome). Associated signs may include mild ptosis and facial anhidrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left oculomotor nerve: Parasympathetic fibers run with CN III; a lesion causes a large, poorly reactive pupil (mydriasis) with anisocoria worse in bright light, plus ptosis and ophthalmoplegia—doesn’t fit this case.

 

Option B. Left parasympathetic pathway: Parasympathetic defects produce a larger pupil that fails to constrict, making anisocoria greater in light and on the affected (left) side—opposite of the findings.

 

Option C. Left optic nerve: An afferent defect (RAPD) alters light responses but does not cause anisocoria; pupil sizes remain symmetric though the direct/consensual responses are asymmetric.

questions.text: Which of these disorders was earlier known as minimal brain dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder

 

Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) was historically referred to as “Minimal Brain Dysfunction (MBD)” — a term used in the mid-20th century to describe children with learning and behavioral problems despite having normal intelligence and no identifiable structural brain lesion.

 

The concept of MBD evolved as understanding improved: researchers recognized that the core features were inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, leading to the modern term ADHD in DSM-III (described in 1980).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dyslexia: A specific learning disorder involving difficulty in reading, writing, or spelling, unrelated to hyperactivity or impulsivity.

 

Option C. Mental subnormality: An outdated term for intellectual disability, characterized by low IQ and adaptive deficits, not behavioral dysregulation.

 

Option D. Oligophrenia: Another older term for intellectual disability, not linked to attention or hyperactivity problems.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a painless swelling in his right medial face since a few months. The MRI image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucocele

 

The MRI shows a well-defined, expansile lesion in the right maxillary sinus with characteristic features of fluid retention and sinus expansion without aggressive bone destruction, consistent with a mucocele.

 

The clinical presentation of painless, progressive swelling in the medial face, along with the described MRI findings, most likely represents a Mucocele.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Maxillary sinusitis: Maxillary sinusitis typically presents with signs of infection and mucosal thickening, not expansile cystic lesions.

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a vascular tumor usually affecting adolescent males and arises near the nasopharynx, often with nasal obstruction and epistaxis.

 

Option D. Inverted papilloma: Inverted papilloma is a benign epithelial tumor that commonly shows unilateral nasal obstruction with papillomatous masses but does not cause expansive sinus fluid retention as seen here.

choices.text: Age of onset of initial depressive episode

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the OPD due to persistent sadness, weight gain, and fatigue over the past 4 months. The patient is a dentist who has had difficulty waking up in the morning for clinic. He says, "I used to be really efficient, but now I always run 2 hours behind schedule." Following a divorce 3 years ago, the patient was diagnosed with major depressive disorder, which improved after a few months of treatment with paroxetine. Physical examination and laboratory evaluation are normal. After discussion of treatment options, the patient is started on sertraline. His symptoms resolve by the follow-up appointment 6 months later. Which of the following features is an indication for long-term maintenance of antidepressant therapy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Number of prior depressive episodes

 

  • The number of prior depressive episodes is the strongest predictor for the need for long-term (maintenance) antidepressant therapy.
  • Clinical guidelines recommend:
    • First depressive episode: Continue antidepressant for 6–9 months after remission.
    • ≥2 episodes: Continue for at least 1–3 years (continuation or maintenance phase).
    • ≥3 or chronic episodes: Consider lifelong maintenance therapy to prevent recurrence.
  • This patient has had at least two major depressive episodes (one 3 years ago and one current), indicating a recurrent major depressive disorder, hence long-term treatment is justified.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age of onset of initial depressive episode: Early onset may predict chronicity but does not independently determine maintenance therapy duration.

 

Option B. Duration of current depressive episode: Longer duration may require longer acute-phase therapy, but maintenance therapy is based on recurrence risk.

 

Option D. Presence of atypical depressive features: Affects choice of antidepressant (e.g., MAOI response) but not duration of maintenance therapy.

questions.text: From which of the following structures does the saccule develop?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Pars inferior

questions.text: Identify the incorrect diagnosis pair:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital pseudotumor

 

 

Among the four neuro-orbital MRI/CT images shown, the second image (labeled as B) does not correspond correctly to the diagnosis of orbital pseudotumor — hence, it’s the incorrect diagnosis pair.

 

Let’s analyze each image and correlate with the correct radiologic diagnosis:

 

A. Meningioma:

 

  • Image appearance: Extra-axial, dural-based enhancing mass often showing “dural tail sign”.
  • MRI finding: Homogeneous enhancement, broad dural attachment, hyperostosis of adjacent bone may be seen.
  • Diagnosis: Meningioma (Correct match).

 

B. Orbital pseudotumor:

 

Expected appearance: Diffuse, ill-defined, enhancing soft-tissue lesion involving extraocular muscles (including tendons), lacrimal gland, or retrobulbar fat; usually unilateral.

  • Actual image shown: Axial orbital CT at level of Eyes with severe fusiform medial rectus enlargement seen in THYROID EYE DISEASE[TED].
  • Diagnosis: TED, thus Incorrect pairing.

 

 

Option C. Optic nerve glioma:

 

  • Typical MRI features:
    • Fusiform enlargement of the optic nerve
    • Iso- to hypointense on T1, hyperintense on T2
    • Often seen in children and associated with neurofibromatosis type 1.
  • Diagnosis: Optic nerve glioma (Correct match).

 

Option D. Optic nerve meningioma:

 

  • MRI findings:
    • Tram-track sign (enhancing meninges encircling a non-enhancing optic nerve)
    • May show calcification on CT
    • Common in middle-aged women.
  • Diagnosis: Optic nerve meningioma (Correct match).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the OPD by her husband due to his concern about her increasing social withdrawal. The patient prefers to stay at home. When she must run errands, she insists that her husband accompany her. She stopped working 2 years ago due to severe episodes of anxiety that would occur unpredictably for no apparent reason. Since that time, the patient has continued to experience these episodes several times a week and has become more socially isolated due to fears of having another episode. The patient feels badly that she is no longer working and contributing to the household finances. She has occasional difficulty falling asleep and problems with concentration. Although she is not looking for work, she keeps her home clean, cooks nightly, and enjoys watching television. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's social withdrawal?
questions.solution: Ans. C)﻿﻿﻿ Panic disorder

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with leukocoria in the left eye. The CT is shown below. The most likely mutated gene is on the same chromosome as which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) BRCA2

 

The image shows a CT orbit/brain with calcified intraocular mass in a child presenting with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) — classic for retinoblastoma.

 

Now, relating to the question:

 

They ask:

 

“The most likely mutated gene is on the same chromosome as which of the following genes?”

 

The RB1 gene is located on chromosome 13q14,
and the BRCA2 gene is also located on chromosome 13q12.3.

 

Genetic basis:

 

  • Caused by mutation of the RB1 gene (a tumor suppressor gene)
  • Chromosomal location: 13q14

 

Loss of both RB1 alleles (Knudson’s "two-hit" hypothesis) → loss of cell cycle control at G1-S checkpoint, leading to uncontrolled proliferation of retinal cells.

 

Key points:

 

Retinoblastoma

 

  • Most common primary intraocular malignancy in children
  • Presentation: Leukocoria, strabismus, proptosis, or orbital mass
  • CT finding: Intraocular calcification (diagnostic hallmark)

questions.text: What is defined as the emotional release and discharge after consciously reliving a painful experience that has been repressed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abreaction

 

Abreaction is the process in which a patient consciously re-experiences and relives a repressed painful or traumatic event and, in doing so, releases the associated emotions. This emotional release helps bring unconscious material to awareness and can be therapeutic. It was originally described in psychoanalytic therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catharsis: Catharsis refers to a more general emotional release, often by expressing strong emotions through art, drama, or discussion. Unlike abreaction, it does not necessarily involve reliving repressed traumatic experiences.

 

Option C. Venting out: Venting out means openly expressing emotions such as anger or frustration in daily life. It is not specifically tied to repressed memories and does not carry the therapeutic depth of abreaction.

 

Option D. Guided relaxation: This is a therapeutic technique in which patients use breathing exercises, imagery, and muscle relaxation to reduce anxiety and stress. It is unrelated to the reliving of repressed painful experiences.

questions.text: An 85-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to worsening eye pain. Physical examination shows scattered vesicles on the left side of the forehead and nose and on the left upper and lower eyelids. Fluorescein staining is shown below. Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Varicella-zoster virus

 

Vesicular rash confined to the V1 (ophthalmic) dermatome—forehead, eyelids, and tip/side of the nose (Hutchinson sign)—with ocular pain and the fluorescein pattern of branching “pseudodendrites” without terminal bulbs is classic for herpes zoster ophthalmicus, due to reactivation of VZV. It can cause keratitis, uveitis, and elevated IOP; treat urgently with systemic antivirals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenovirus: Typically causes epidemic keratoconjunctivitis with watery discharge, follicular conjunctivitis, preauricular lymphadenopathy, and later subepithelial infiltrates—no dermatomal vesicles and no zoster pseudo-dendrites.

 

 

Option B. Candida albicans: Causes fungal keratitis, often after vegetative trauma or with contact lenses/immunosuppression. Slit-lamp shows feathery stromal infiltrates and possible satellite lesions, not dermatomal skin vesicles.

 

 

Option C. Herpes simplex virus: HSV epithelial keratitis shows true dendritic ulcers with terminal bulbs that stain brightly with fluorescein and rose bengal, usually without a dermatomal vesicular rash. Here, the cutaneous V1 involvement points to VZV, not HSV.

choices.text: Comma-shaped and grows well in high pH

questions.text: A 70-year-old diabetic woman comes to the physician complaining of progressive, severe pain and discharge from her left ear for the past 2 days. On examination, moving or touching the pinna produces extreme pain. Otoscopic examination shows granulation tissue in the left ear canal with a scant amount of discharge. Which of the following microbiological characteristics best describes the infecting organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Motile and oxidase positive

 

This elderly diabetic woman presents with malignant otitis externa, a severe infection of the external auditory canal often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The presence of granulation tissue in the ear canal is highly characteristic.
Pseudomonas is a Gram-negative rod, motile (flagella present), and oxidase positive. It thrives in moist environments and is notorious for causing infections in immunocompromised and diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Comma-shaped and grows well in high pH: This refers to Vibrio cholerae, which is comma-shaped, grows in alkaline pH, and causes watery diarrhea (rice-water stools), not ear infections.

 

Option B. Fast lactose fermenter: Organisms like Escherichia coli and Klebsiella are rapid lactose fermenters (pink colonies on MacConkey agar). They are common in urinary and gastrointestinal infections, not malignant otitis externa.

 

Option D. Nonmotile and a lactose nonfermenter: This describes Shigella species, which are nonmotile, non-lactose fermenters. They cause dysentery with blood and mucus in stools, not ear canal infections.

choices.text: It bypasses upper airway structures from nose to larynx thereby reducing the dead space by 50%.
Usually done at the level of 2nd to 3rd tracheal rings.
High tracheostomy (1st ring) done along with surgeries related to cancer larynx.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the device shown below except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) An uncuffed tube is preferred

 

The device shown is a tracheostomy tube. Among the statements, the incorrect one is:

 

An uncuffed tube is preferred.

 

  • Cuffed tubes are usually preferred in adults, especially in needing mechanical ventilation.
  • A cuffed tracheostomy tube prevents aspiration and allows positive-pressure ventilation.
  • Uncuffed tubes are generally used in children (to avoid tracheal injury due to smaller airway diameter) or in long-term weaning once aspiration risk is low.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. It bypasses upper airway structures from nose to larynx thereby reducing the dead space by 50 percent: This is correct. A tracheostomy provides a direct airway into the trachea, bypassing the nasal cavity, oral cavity, pharynx, and larynx. By doing this, it reduces the anatomical dead space by approximately half, which helps improve ventilation efficiency and decreases the work of breathing.

 

Option B. Usually done at the level of 2nd to 3rd tracheal rings: This is correct. The standard site for performing a tracheostomy is between the second and third tracheal rings. This avoids complications of going too high (risk of subglottic stenosis and cricoid injury) or too low (risk of injury to large vessels such as the innominate artery).

 

Option C. High tracheostomy (1st ring) done along with surgeries related to cancer larynx: This is correct. In patients undergoing surgery for laryngeal carcinoma, a high tracheostomy at the first tracheal ring may be done. This helps avoid tumor contamination and allows proper exposure for laryngectomy procedures.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he was found by police trying to break into the back office of a grocery store, claiming that he worked there and that he had left his keys in the office. The owner of the grocery denied that the patient was employed. The patient's medical problems include hypertension, hyperlipidemia, major depressive disorder, alcohol use disorder, and type 2 diabetes mellitus.  The patient answers questions without difficuity but provides conflicting information to different examiners. He is unable to account for how he ended up in the grocery store; however, he does provide detailed accounts of his previous job as an English professor, even reciting Shakespeare's Macbeth at length. He does not appear troubled by his inability to recall events accurately. The remainder of the examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ﻿﻿﻿Korsakoff syndrome

 

This patient presents with confabulation (inventing stories to fill memory gaps), disorientation, and memory impairment in the setting of chronic alcohol use disorder — classic for Korsakoff syndrome, a late neuropsychiatric manifestation of thiamine (vitamin B₁) deficiency.

 

Korsakoff syndrome typically follows Wernicke encephalopathy (the acute phase with confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia) if not adequately treated with thiamine. It is associated with bilateral damage to the mammillary bodies and dorsomedial thalamic nuclei.

 

Key Features:

 

  • Severe anterograde and retrograde amnesia
  • Confabulation (fabrication of stories to cover memory loss)
  • Lack of insight and apathy
  • Preserved long-term memory and intellectual function
  • Not distressed by memory loss (unlike dissociative amnesia)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alzheimer disease: Causes progressive global cognitive decline (memory, language, executive function), not isolated amnesia with confabulation and alcohol history.

 

Option B. Dissociative amnesia: Characterized by inability to recall important personal information, usually after psychological stress/trauma; confabulation is absent, and patients often show distress about memory gaps. Treatment is Psychotherapy.

 

Option D. Marchiafava-Bignami disease: A rare alcohol-related demyelination and necrosis of the corpus callosum causing seizures, spasticity, dysarthria, and dementia, not isolated confabulatory amnesia. 

 

 

Image showing corpus callosum thinning

Immature senile cataract
Rosette cataract
Mytotonic dystrophy

questions.solution: Ans. B) Immature senile cataract

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma and surgical management was done. The post-operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Total laryngectomy

 

  • The image shows a permanent stoma in the neck (laryngectomy stoma), with the airway opening directly to the exterior.
  • This is not a temporary tracheostomy (which would have a tube in place and could later be closed).
  • Instead, this is a permanent separation of the airway from the upper respiratory tract, which is done in total laryngectomy.

 

Total laryngectomy:

 

  • Entire larynx (including vocal cords) is removed.
  • Indicated in advanced laryngeal carcinoma.
  • Results in:
    • Permanent tracheostoma (breathing only via stoma, not nose/mouth).
    • Loss of natural voice → patient may require voice rehabilitation (esophageal speech, electrolarynx, or tracheoesophageal puncture prosthesis).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Partial laryngectomy:

 

  • Preserves part of the larynx and voice.
  • Does not result in a permanent stoma.

 

Option B. Percutaneous tracheostomy:

 

  • Temporary airway access through trachea, usually with a tube in place.
  • Stoma would close after tube removal.

 

Option C. Standard tracheostomy:

 

  • Temporary opening with tube; the upper airway is still connected.
  • Different appearance from a permanent laryngectomy stoma.

choices.text: Occurs gradually over a period of time

questions.text: Which of the following features is more in favor of delirium?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluctuating course

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute onset and fluctuating course of symptoms. The level of consciousness and attention varies throughout the day, often worsening at night (sundowning). It is an indicator of underlying organic dysfunction and differentiates delirium from chronic conditions like dementia or psychosis. The fluctuating nature of symptoms is a hallmark of delirium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Occurs gradually over a period of time: Delirium develops acutely over hours to days, whereas a gradual course is more typical of dementia.

 

Option C. Preserved consciousness: Consciousness is impaired in delirium with fluctuating alertness, unlike in dementia or psychiatric illnesses where it is preserved.

 

Option D. Commonly associated with auditory hallucinations: Visual hallucinations are more common in delirium, while auditory hallucinations are characteristic of psychiatric disorders like schizophrenia.

 

Summary Table: Delirium vs Dementia:

questions.text: A female patient with hearing loss is examined and is found to be Rinne’s negative at 256 Hz and 512 Hz, while Rinne positive at 1024 Hz. What is the expected air conduction and bone conduction gap?
questions.solution: Ans. A) 30-45 dB

questions.text: A 53-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed GTCS seizure 1 hour prior. The patient regained consciousness after 1-2 minutes. Medical history includes schizoaffective disorder with multiple hospitalizations for psychotic and mood episodes beginning at age 22. On physical examination, the patient is awake and alert. A 1-cm laceration is noted on the right side of the tongue. Serum chemistry is normal. A CT scan of the head reveals no abnormalities. Which of the following medications most likely contributed to this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clozapine

 

Clozapine is the most effective antipsychotic for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder, but it carries several significant adverse effects — one of which is a dose-dependent risk of seizures.

 

Mechanism:


Clozapine lowers the seizure threshold, particularly at higher doses (>600 mg/day), due to its potent anticholinergic and antihistaminic properties. This patient’s generalized tonic–clonic seizure (GTCS) with no metabolic or structural cause points to clozapine-induced seizure.

 

Other major adverse effects of clozapine:

 

  • Agranulocytosis (requires routine WBC/ANC monitoring)
  • Myocarditis/cardiomyopathy
  • Metabolic syndrome (weight gain, dyslipidaemia, insulin resistance)
  • Sialorrhea and constipation
  • Seizures (dose-related)

 

Note: Clozapine is the only antipsychotic with proven anti-suicidal benefit, but it carries dose-related seizure risk, requiring careful monitoring and dose adjustment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Buspirone: A partial 5-HT₁A agonist used for generalized anxiety disorder; it is non-sedating, non-addictive, and does not cause seizures.

 

Option B. Carbamazepine: An anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer that prevents seizures, not causes them (though it can cause hyponatremia or agranulocytosis).

 

Option C. Citalopram: An SSRI; may rarely cause hyponatremia or QT prolongation, but not seizures at therapeutic doses.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic male develops unilateral facial pain and loosening of teeth. MRI is shown below. Which of the following histopathological appearances is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspetate, ribbon shaped hyphae

 

This diabetic patient with unilateral facial pain, loosening of teeth, and the shown MRI and oral findings is most likely suffering from mucormycosis (rhino-orbito-cerebral type). In mucormycosis, histopathology will show broad, aseptate, ribbon-shaped hyphae, which invade blood vessels and tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septate hyphae: Which are divided by regular cross-walls, are characteristic of Aspergillus species. Under the microscope, Aspergillus shows thin, septate hyaline (light-colored) hyphae with acute angle branching, usually around 45 degrees. This feature helps distinguish it from mucormycosis, which shows broad, aseptate, ribbon-like hyphae.

 

Option C. True yeast: Forms are seen in fungi such as Cryptococcus, which reproduce by budding and typically appear as round or oval cells with a capsule. 

 

Option D. Pseudo-yeast: Or pseudohyphae are elongated yeast cells attached end-to-end, often seen in Candida species, resembling hyphae but with constrictions at septal junctions. Neither true yeast nor pseudo-yeast forms are found in mucormycosis

questions.text: Which of the following has a poor prognosis with exposure and response prevention in OCD?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hoarding

 

Exposure and response prevention (ERP) is a highly effective cognitive-behavioral therapy for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). However, patients with hoarding subtype of OCD respond poorly to ERP compared to other subtypes. Hoarding involves persistent difficulty discarding possessions regardless of value, leading to significant distress and functional impairment. It is often ego-syntonic (feels natural to the patient), resistant to change, and associated with poor treatment adherence and outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathological doubt: Patients have recurrent doubts (eg, “Did I lock the door?”). ERP is effective as patients can be exposed to the anxiety-provoking situation and prevented from checking repeatedly, leading to improvement.

 

Option B. Magical thinking: Patients believe that certain thoughts or rituals prevent harmful events (eg, “If I count to 7, my mother will not die”). ERP works reasonably well here by challenging the compulsion and showing that feared outcomes do not occur.

 

Option D. Contamination obsession: This is one of the most common OCD presentations (eg, fear of dirt, germs). ERP has good efficacy by exposing patients to contamination triggers and preventing washing or cleaning rituals.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to "feeling anxious and down" for the past 2 weeks. The patient cries frequently and has been making mistakes in her accounting job due to poor concentration. She feels tense throughout the day and has difficulty staying asleep most nights because she is awakened by episodes of palpitations, shortness of breath, and sweating. The patient was mugged 3 weeks ago while walking home from work but is reluctant to discuss what happened. She does not use alcohol or illicit drugs and takes no medication. On mental status examination, the patient makes minimal eye contact, looks down at the floor, and wrings her hands repeatedly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute stress disorder

 

This patient developed anxiety, intrusive distress, hyperarousal, poor concentration, and avoidance within 3 weeks of a traumatic event (mugging). These symptoms have been present for less than 1 month, which fits the diagnosis of acute stress disorder (ASD).

 

Acute Stress Disorder – Key Diagnostic Features:

 

  • Onset:  Within 3 days to 1 month after a traumatic event.
  • Symptoms:
    • Intrusive memories or flashbacks
    • Avoidance of trauma-related stimuli
    • Negative mood and dissociation
    • Hyperarousal (palpitations, sweating, insomnia, irritability)
  • Duration:  Symptoms persist <1 month.
  • If symptoms persist >1 month, the diagnosis changes to Post-traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD): It is characterized by chronic, excessive, and uncontrollable worry about various aspects of life such as work, health, or family for at least 6 months. Physical symptoms like muscle tension, restlessness, fatigue, and sleep disturbance are common. The anxiety is not related to a specific trauma or event and persists most days, impairing daily functioning.

 

Option C. Panic disorder: Involves recurrent unexpected panic attacks with intense fear of losing control or dying, not trauma-related and typically not associated with avoidance or flashbacks.

 

Option D. Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD): PTSD develops after exposure to a traumatic or life-threatening event, with the same symptom clusters seen in acute stress disorder: intrusive memories or flashbacks, avoidance of reminders, negative mood or thoughts, and hyperarousal (irritability, insomnia, exaggerated startle).
However, the key distinction is duration ≥1 month and symptoms often lead to marked functional impairment in work or relationships.
If left untreated, PTSD can become chronic, requiring trauma-focused cognitive behavioural therapy and SSRIs/SNRIs as first-line treatments.

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaint of loss of wrinkles on forehead, inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected?

questions.text: 56-year-old previously healthy man comes to the OPD due to decreased hearing in both ears. He reports difficulty understanding conversations in crowded rooms. For the past 12 years, he has worked in a factory where he has to shout to communicate with coworkers and has seldom worn hearing protection. An audiogram is obtained as shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely abnormal in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Organ of Corti

 

  • The audiogram shows a bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with a notch at 4 kHz, which is the classic pattern for noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL).
  • The patient has worked in a noisy environment (factory) for years without protection → most consistent with NIHL.

 

Pathophysiology of NIHL:

 

  • Prolonged exposure to loud sounds damages the outer hair cells of the Organ of Corti (especially at the basal turn of cochlea).
  • This produces a characteristic “noise notch” at 4,000 Hz on audiogram.
  • Speech discrimination becomes difficult, especially in noisy environments (difficulty in crowded rooms).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auditory nerve: Damage would cause sensorineural loss but not specifically the 4 kHz “noise notch.” More typical of retro-cochlear pathology (eg, acoustic neuroma).

 

Option B. Cochlear cupula: Refers to the apex of cochlea, important for low-frequency hearing. NIHL affects basal turn (high frequencies) first, not apex.

 

Option C. Middle ear ossicles: Cause conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural. Audiogram would show an air-bone gap.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after having a seizure at home. Her mother says that the girl has had a mild headache and fatigue for the past few days. CT scan of the head is shown in the image below. Which of the following historical details is most relevant in establishing this patient's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recent episode of otitis media

 

  • The CT scan shows a ring-enhancing lesion with surrounding edema in the temporal lobe.
  • This is classic for a brain abscess.
  • In children, the most common cause is direct extension from infections of the middle ear (otitis media) or mastoiditis → leading to a temporal lobe abscess.
  • Clinical presentation: fever, headache, seizures, focal neurologic signs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Family history of seizures: Relevant for epilepsy, but CT shows a mass lesion (abscess), not  specifically suggestive of primary seizure disorder.

 

Option B. Maternal history of perinatal infection: May be relevant for congenital TORCH infections, but here the acute ring-enhancing lesion points to abscess.

 

Option C. Previous recurrent gingival bleeding: Suggests hematologic disorder (eg, platelet defect), not related to abscess formation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male complains of painless bilateral visual difficulty that has progressed over the last year. Fundoscopy is shown.  Which of the following would you expect most on visual field examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Central scotomas

 

The fundus image shows age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) — a degenerative disease affecting the macula (central retina), responsible for detailed central vision.

 

The macula contains a high density of cone photoreceptors vital for fine visual acuity, color perception, and reading vision.
When it degenerates, central vision is lost, while peripheral vision remains intact, leading to central scotomas on visual field testing.

 

Key Fundus Findings in ARMD:

 

  • Drusen deposits (yellowish spots) in the macular area — extracellular material between Bruch’s membrane and the retinal pigment epithelium.
  • Retinal pigment epithelial changes (mottling or atrophy).
  • May progress to geographic atrophy (dry ARMD) or choroidal neovascularization with hemorrhage/exudate (wet ARMD).

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Painless, gradual central vision loss
  • Metamorphopsia (distorted vision)
  • Difficulty reading, recognizing faces

 

Other Options Explained:

 

Option A. Bitemporal hemianopsia: 

 

  • Caused by optic chiasm compression (e.g., pituitary adenoma).
  • Produces loss of temporal visual fields in both eyes, not central vision loss.

 

Option B. Arcuate scotomas: 

 

  • Seen in glaucoma due to optic nerve damage.
  • Visual loss follows the arcuate nerve fiber pattern in the mid-periphery, sparing the central field initially.

 

Option D. Macular sparing: 

 

  • Occurs in occipital lobe infarcts (posterior cerebral artery occlusion).
  • The macular area is spared due to dual blood supply from the middle cerebral artery, hence peripheral vision loss but preserved central vision — opposite of this case.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with bipolar disorder comes to the OPD for follow-up. The patient was diagnosed and treated for a manic episode at age 29 and has been stable on a combination of lithium and risperidone. After a staff meeting a few weeks ago, her supervisor said she was repeatedly frowning while others were presenting. Since then, the patient has been increasingly self-conscious and has started eating lunch alone at her desk. Physical examination is unremarkable except for occasional grimacing and slow inversion and tapping movements of her right foot. Lithium level is 0.9 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacological management?
questions.solution:
﻿﻿﻿Ans. D) Taper and discontinue risperidone

 

This patient presents with involuntary facial grimacing and choreoathetoid limb movements after chronic use of risperidone — consistent with tardive dyskinesia (TD), a late-onset extrapyramidal side effect (EPS) caused by long-term dopamine D₂ receptor blockade by antipsychotics.

 

TD results from dopamine receptor super-sensitivity and upregulation in the basal ganglia following prolonged D₂ inhibition.

 

The most appropriate management is to taper and discontinue risperidone, the offending agent, if clinically feasible. If antipsychotic treatment is still required, it should be switched to an agent with minimal D₂ blockade, such as clozapine or quetiapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Add benztropine: Used for acute dystonia or parkinsonism (early EPS), not for tardive dyskinesia; anticholinergics can worsen TD.

 

Option B. Add daily propranolol: Effective for akathisia (subjective restlessness), not for involuntary movements like TD.

 

Option C. Discontinue lithium and start valproic acid: The patient’s lithium level is therapeutic (0.9 mEq/L), and the movement symptoms are due to risperidone, not lithium toxicity.

 

Summary Table: Extrapyramidal Side Effects[D2 blockage at NIGRO-STRIATAL PATHWAY by Typical Antipsychotics] [ADAPT]

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police officers after he was found wandering aimlessly at an airport. The man is alert and answers questions appropriately; however, he appears to be confused about his identity and does not recognize the name on his driver's license in his wallet. Extensive inquiry fails to reveal any helpful information as the patient is perplexed and does not remember where he lives, how he got to the airport, his family members, or his profession. His cognitive function is otherwise intact. A search of his personal belongings reveals an airline ticket from Las Vegas to Arlington, Virginia. An emergency contact on the patient's phone leads to his wife, who reports that her husband "just disappeared" after he found out that his father had passed away that morning. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
﻿﻿Ans. D) Dissociative amnesia

 

This patient presents with inability to recall important personal information, especially after a severe psychological stressor (father’s death), along with preserved orientation and normal cognition, which are characteristic of dissociative amnesia.


The presence of aimless wandering or travel (as seen at the airport) further indicates dissociative fugue, a subtype of dissociative amnesia.

 

Key features of Dissociative Amnesia:

 

  • Inability to recall autobiographical information (name, address, past life events)
  • Triggered by stress or trauma
  • Consciousness and cognitive function are intact
  • May be associated with fugue state — wandering with confusion about identity
  • Reversible; memory typically returns spontaneously or with therapy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute stress disorder: This condition develops within 3 days to 1 month after exposure to a traumatic or life-threatening event. It is characterized by symptoms of intrusive distressing memories, flashbacks, avoidance of reminders, negative mood, and hyperarousal (e.g., insomnia, irritability, exaggerated startle). However, personal identity and memory are preserved, and there is no fugue state or wandering behavior as seen in dissociative amnesia.

 

Option B. Brief psychotic disorder: Involves a sudden onset of psychotic symptoms such as delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, or disorganized/catatonic behavior lasting less than 1 month, often precipitated by stress. In contrast, this patient is alert, coherent, and reality-oriented without any evidence of psychosis or thought disorganization, which rules out this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Depersonalization/derealization disorder: Characterized by persistent or recurrent experiences of detachment either from oneself (depersonalization) or from the environment (derealization). The individual feels as though they are observing themselves or that the world around them is unreal. Importantly, memory, identity, and reality testing remain intact, unlike in dissociative amnesia where autobiographical memory is lost.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the OPD with her husband due to behavioral changes over the past 6 weeks. The husband says, "She's not an angry person, but ever since she was in a car accident, little things seem to set her off. She yells and honks at people for not using their turn signals and gets upset when we have to wait for a table at restaurants." The patient describes difficulty sleeping due to thoughts "swirling" in her head and feeling panicked every time she wakes up. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Recommend cognitive-behavioral therapy 

 

This patient’s symptoms of irritability, hyperarousal, intrusive thoughts, sleep disturbance, and panic following a car accident (traumatic event) suggest features of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) (depending on duration).


The first-line management for both PTSD is trauma-focused cognitive-behavioural therapy, which helps the patient process the traumatic event, reduce avoidance and fear responses, and restructure maladaptive thoughts.

 

CBT benefits:

 

  • Reduces anxiety and emotional reactivity
  • Improves coping and sleep
  • Prevents progression from acute stress disorder to chronic PTSD

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Begin buspirone: Used for generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) with chronic, non-trauma-related worry. It has no role in trauma-related anxiety or acute stress reactions.

 

Option B. Provide reassurance and prescribe short - term  alprazolam: Benzodiazepines may offer temporary symptom relief but are not recommended as first-line therapy for trauma-related anxiety due to risk of dependence, sedation, and worsening long-term recovery.

 

Option D. Start lithium: A mood stabilizer used in bipolar disorder, not indicated for anxiety, irritability, or trauma-related symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For recent trauma-related anxiety and hyperarousal → CBT is the most effective and preventive therapy.

questions.solution: Ans. A) Earache

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to hearing loss in her right ear. A week ago, the patient developed symptoms of nasal congestion, cough, and rhinorrhea. Three days ago, she traveled from New York to Delhi. On her return flight yesterday, the patient developed hearing loss and severe pain in her right ear and noticed a drop of blood on her finger when she scratched her ear canal. All symptoms have resolved except for persistent hearing loss in the right ear. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reassurance and follow-up examination

 

The otoscopic image shows a small central perforation of the tympanic membrane with some blood staining. The history is typical of barotrauma-induced tympanic membrane rupture:

 

  • Preceding upper respiratory tract infection → causes eustachian tube dysfunction.
  • Air travel with pressure changes → leads to sudden middle ear pressure imbalance.
  • This results in acute tympanic membrane perforation with pain, bleeding, and hearing loss.

 

Natural Course

 

  • Most traumatic or barotrauma-related tympanic membrane perforations heal spontaneously within a few weeks.
  • Hearing usually recovers as the membrane heals.
  • The correct management is conservative:
    • Keep the ear dry (no water entry).
    • Avoid ear drops unless infected.
    • Follow-up to check healing in 4–6 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aural irrigation: Contraindicated in tympanic membrane perforation, as it risks middle ear infection.

 

Option B. Oxymetazoline: Topical nasal decongestants[alpha agonists] are sometimes used for eustachian tube dysfunction but are not required after a clear perforation has occurred.

 

Option D. Tympanoplasty:

 

  • Surgical repair is indicated only if the perforation persists beyond 2–3 months, or if recurrent infections occur.
  • Not the first step.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of bipolar disorder with psychotic features comes to the office for evaluation of infertility. The patient's last menstrual period was 4 months ago; her menses tend to be erratic, occurring every 30-60 days and lasting 4-8 days. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient's infertility?
questions.solution: ﻿﻿﻿Ans. D) Risperidone

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to sudden onset difficulty breathing. The patient developed a mild cough and sore throat yesterday, his parents gave him acetaminophen, which improved his throat pain.  Temperature is 39.1 C (102.4 F), blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg, pulse is 130/min, and respirations are 46/min. Oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. The patient appears anxious, is drooling, and has inspiratory stridor. The uvula is midline, and there is no oropharyngeal or tonsillar erythema. Lung examination shows transmitted upper airway noises without wheezing or crackles. Which of the following is the most likely finding on imaging?
questions.solution: Ans. A) A.

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Cavernous sinus thrombosis

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the OPD due to erectile dysfunction and decreased libido for the past month. The patient has never experienced these symptoms before and finds them to be very upsetting. The patient has a history of schizophrenia and was discharged from a psychiatric hospital 3 months ago on risperidone. He has no current delusions, and his auditory hallucinations have decreased in frequency and intensity. Review of systems is negative except for a recent 3-kg (6.6-b) weight gain. Physical examination shows bilateral breast enlargement. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism responsible for this patient's decreased libido?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Decreased dopamine activity in the tuberoinfundibular pathway

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the office due to oral pain. For the last 3 days, she has had mild pain in the left lower jaw associated with swelling of the gums. The patient had a loose molar extracted 3 weeks ago, and the extraction site never completely healed. Medical history is notable for osteoporosis treated with calcium, vitamin D, and zoledronic acid. She has never used tobacco or alcohol. Vital signs are normal. Examination shows gingival edema and erythema surrounding an area of exposed bone at the left lower jaw. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B)﻿﻿﻿ Osteonecrosis

questions.text: During psychotherapy, the therapist had mixed conscious and unconscious feelings towards his patient. This is known as.
questions.solution: Ans. A) Countertransference

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of schizoaffective disorder is admitted to the hospital for treatment of a lower extremity cellulitis. He is continued on his home medications-lithium, risperidone, and sertraline-and cephalosporin therapy is initiated to treat his infection. His infection improves over the next 10-14 days, but prior to discharge, he develops repeated episodes of vomiting and diarrhea. At the same time, the patient becomes tremulous and uncoordinated, which makes it difficult for him to walk without falling. In addition, he seems confused. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows fasciculations and bilateral tremor. Which of the following medications is most likely to have caused this?
questions.solution: Ans. A) ﻿﻿﻿Lithium

questions.solution: Ans. C) Squeeze technique

questions.text: A 38-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-month history of depressed mood. After physical examination and laboratory workup, major depressive disorder is diagnosed and antidepressant therapy is initiated. The patients symptoms do not respond to monotherapy, so an antipsychotic medication is added. Over the course of several months, the patient's antidepressant dose is increased to the maximal therapeutic dose. At his 6-month follow-up, he has also new-onset hypertension. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of this adverse effect?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Venlafaxine

questions.text: The image of a drug is given below. It is used in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Subglottic stenosis

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0 at 30 weeks gestation, comes to the OPD due to increasing difficulty hearing, especially on the right side. A tuning fork held over the middle of the forehead sounds louder in the right ear. Tuning fork sounds are better heard with bone conduction on the right side and with air conduction on the left. The remainder of the neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D)﻿﻿﻿ Otosclerosis

 

This pregnant woman has progressive conductive hearing loss with tuning fork findings consistent with right-sided conductive deafness.

 

  • Weber test: Lateralizes to the right ear → suggests conductive hearing loss on right side.
  • Rinne test: On right side → BC > AC = negative Rinne (conductive loss). On left side → AC > BC = normal.
  • Clinical history: Young woman, pregnant (hormonal changes accelerate otosclerosis).

 

Otosclerosis is caused by abnormal bone remodeling at the stapes footplate, leading to stapes fixation and conductive hearing loss. Symptoms worsen during pregnancy due to increased hormonal influences.

 

In patients with otosclerosis, the characteristic "Carhart's notch" on an audiogram may reflect worsening hearing during pregnancy, though the precise causal link is debated. This condition involves abnormal bone growth in the middle ear and affects women more often than men.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic otitis media: Causes conductive hearing loss but would typically present with ear discharge, tympanic membrane abnormalities, or recurrent infections. None mentioned here.

 

Option B. Medication ototoxicity:

 

  • Eg, aminoglycosides, cisplatin.
  • Causes sensorineural hearing loss, usually bilateral, not conductive loss.

 

Option C. Ménière disease:

 

  • Inner ear disorder → episodic vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss.
  • No vertigo in this case and findings are conductive, not SNHL.

choices.text: Pass a catheter through the nares

questions.text: A 1-hour-old boy is evaluated in the newbor nursery for feeding difficulty. He was able to latch and begin feeding but within 1 minute, his face developed a blue tinge. The boy cried, and his color improved.  Chest radiograph is normal. Which of the following is the best next step in evaluation of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D)﻿﻿﻿ Pass a catheter through the nares

 

  • The newborn develops cyanosis while feeding but improves with crying.
  • Key point: Newborns are obligate nasal breathers.
  • When the infant tries to breathe through the nose during feeding, the obstruction leads to cyanosis.
  • Crying forces the infant to breathe through the mouth → color improves.
  • This is classic for choanal atresia (congenital blockage of the posterior nasal apertures).
  • The next best diagnostic step is to pass a soft catheter through each nostril into the nasopharynx.
  • If the catheter cannot be passed, choanal atresia is confirmed.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Draw blood cultures: Would be appropriate if sepsis suspected, but the sudden positional cyanosis relieved by crying is more consistent with choanal atresia, not infection.

 

Option B. Measure blood methemoglobin level: Methemoglobinemia causes persistent cyanosis unresponsive to oxygen, not feeding-related cyanosis.

 

Option C. Obtain an echocardiogram: Needed if congenital heart disease suspected, but the normal chest X-ray and positional cyanosis with crying relief points more towards nasal obstruction.

questions.solution: Ans. A) Ex-Press implant

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the OPD. His mother says that her son's behaviour has been difficult to manage over the past year. "He is always running around (even during dinner), does not listen, and keeps his room a mess. He is always bothering his younger brother, interrupting him when he talks, and taking his toys without asking. The boy's second-grade teacher has reported that he cannot sit still, answers questions impulsively and out of turn, and becomes irritable when she redirects him. The physician recommends a trial of methylphenidate. Which of the following side effects is the patient most likely to experience while taking this medication?
questions.solution:
﻿﻿﻿Ans. B) Decreased appetite

 

Methylphenidate, a central nervous system stimulant and first-line treatment for Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), increases synaptic levels of dopamine and norepinephrine in the brain by inhibiting their reuptake. While highly effective in improving attention and reducing hyperactivity and impulsivity, it commonly causes appetite suppression and weight loss, especially in children.

 

Most common side effects of methylphenidate (and other stimulants like amphetamines):

 

  • Decreased appetite / weight loss (most common)
  • Insomnia (if taken late in the day)
  • Abdominal pain, headache
  • Mild increase in blood pressure and heart rate

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agitation: Although stimulants can cause mild restlessness or irritability, true agitation or manic symptoms are uncommon at therapeutic doses. Such reactions are more likely to occur in cases of overdose, misuse, or in children with an underlying bipolar disorder where stimulants may unmask mania.

 

Option C. Hypersomnia: Methylphenidate is a stimulant, so it typically produces increased alertness and decreased fatigue, not excessive sleepiness. The more likely effect is insomnia, especially if the medication is taken later in the day, due to its stimulating properties.

 

Option D. Tics: Stimulants may unmask or worsen preexisting tics in a small subset of children, but this is relatively uncommon. The risk can be minimized by dose adjustment or switching to nonstimulant options such as atomoxetine. Routine discontinuation is usually not necessary unless tics become severe or disabling.
